Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Transport and Separation through Virus-Structured Nanoporous Membranes

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
McCarthy/Maroo 1264949 / 1264958

The objective of the proposed collaborative research is to investigate transport and separation phenomena through the protein channel of the tobacco mosaic virus (TMV) using an integrated research methodology combining molecular analysis and simulations along with direct experimental characterization. The TMV is a rigid, hollow, rod-shaped plant virus with a 4-nm diameter central pore defined by 2130 helical coat proteins wrapped around a single strand of RNA. It is an extremely stable bio-molecule, withstanding temperatures of up to 60 degrees C and a pH range of 2 to 11. The surface of the central pore is negatively charged, making it attractive for ion exclusion. The outer surface of the TMV has been genetically modified to facilitate near-vertical assembly and metallization onto various materials. This feature provides a mechanism to develop virus-structured membranes using large-scale industrially relevant manufacturing schemes. Due to its stability, structure, surface charge, and manufacturability, the TMV can potentially transform membrane manufacture for biological and chemical separations. This collaborative research project will bring together the expertise of one PI (Maroo) in molecular dynamics simulations and numerical modeling with a second PI (McCarthy) in TMV biotemplating and nanoscale fabrication. The project will focus on the following numerical and experimental investigations: (1) Determination of the surfaces properties of the TMV central pore, (2) Numerical and molecular modeling of overlapping electric double layers, (3) Molecular dynamics simulations of transport and ionic exclusion through the TMV central pore, (4) Fabrication of virus-structured nanoporous membranes using the self-assembly of the TMV, (5) Experimental characterization of transport phenomena through the TMV membranes, and (6) Experimental characterization of separation through the TMV including size and ionic exclusion. The synergy of these two components (numerical and experimental) will result in a comprehensive understanding of transport and separation through the TMV and demonstrate the potential of TMV-structured membranes for water filtration and chemical and biological separations. The advantages of utilizing biological building blocks in nano-engineered systems include low cost, structural versatility, inherent self-assembly properties, and the ability to tune structure through genetic modifications and environmental control. The knowledge base gained in this work will act as a catalyst for future development in the field of separations and the nanomanufacturing of bio-derived membranes.
Broader Impacts. This work will build on the PI's existing participation in Drexel's NSF-funded GK-12 program on the NAE's Grand Challenges (focusing on water desalination) and Syracuse University's Project Engage where the PI holds workshops on modern engineering solutions for K-12 female students. Outreach will extend to pre-college students, particularly those from underrepresented groups in the Philadelphia metropolitan and Syracuse areas and will focus on exposing undergraduates, women, and minorities to multidisciplinary research through integrated research-education initiatives. Undergraduate students at both Drexel and Syracuse will be recruited for research opportunities and participation in the Workshops on Nanoscale Transport through Protein Channels developed by the PIs in the proposed work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biological and chemical separations are ubiquitous processes critical in various industries including materials processing, energy applications, and the purification of solvents. The realization of cost-effect and energy-efficient separation technologies is critical to these applications as well as the health of the global community. The nature of the research project highlights the potential of bio-inspired ion-separation systems to the next generation of engineers, and can lead to the realization of low-cost high-efficiency nanoporous membranes using environmentally friendly and renewable nanomanufacturing methods.

This work has established an in-depth molecular-level understanding of the TMV inner pore which has not been done to date inspite the fact that TMV was the first virus discovered. A representative TMV molecular infinite-pore domain was constructed, allowing for simulations of the pore towards the center of the virus to be conducted for the first time in literature. MD simulation on the transport of ionic solutions in polar and non-polar solvents through the TMV pore was performed. Molecular dynamics simulations were used to (1) characterize the TMV pore surface, (2) evaluate the forces exerted by the pore’s surface on positively charged ions present within the pore, and (3) identify potential surface adsorption locations for positively charged species. Ionic solution transport across the TMV pore was studied, and found that ion separation can be achieved from a solution of non-polar solvent. Screening effect from a polar solvent, such as water, reduced the ion-pore interaction leading to ions transporting across the pore. Thus, the TMV pore can potentially be used as a membrane for ion-separation from non-polar liquids or gases.

Graduate and undergraduate students who worked on the project received training in molecular dynamics simulations, advanced numerical analysis, and gained experience in conference presentation talks, poster presentation and paper writing. A new course 'Fundamentals of Nano-science and Nano-engineering' has been offered, where undergraduate and graduate students are taught about the interaction of molecular forces, as well as molecular dynamics simulations. Students learn how to use GROMACS software and complete individual projects with it.


Last Modified: 05/09/2017
Modified by: Shalabh C Maroo
